snippets.description: Code for downloading websites as .html files.
snippets.name: wget

content.label: commands
content.value:
# install
brew install wget

# code
wget -O YOUR-FILENAME.html URL
wget -P path/to/save/files URL

snippets.description: Code for loading packages and importing primary data/source into Rstudio.
snippets.name: load packages

content.label: install.packages()
content.value:
#-----

## last-update: 
### José Ángel Torrens Hernández

#------
# install packages
install.packages("colortools")
install.packages("corrplot")
install.packages("corrr")
install.packages("data.table")
install.packages("dplyr")
install.packages("fmsb")
install.packages("ggplot2")
install.packages("ggpubr")
install.packages("ggradar")
install.packages("ggrepel")
install.packages("hrbrthemes")
install.packages("janitor")
install.packages("mxmaps")
install.packages("palmerpenguins")
install.packages("RColorBrewer")
install.packages("readxl")
install.packages("scales")
install.packages("stargazer")
install.packages("stringr")
install.packages("unikn")
install.packages("viridis")

content.label: library()
content.value:
# library
library(colortools)
library(corrplot)
library(corrr)
library(data.table)
library(dplyr)
library(fmsb)
library(ggplot2)
library(ggpubr)
library(ggradar)
library(ggrepel)
library(hrbrthemes)
library(janitor)
library(mxmaps)
library(palmerpenguins)
library(RColorBrewer)
library(readxl)
library(scales)
library(stargazer)
library(stringr)
library(unikn)
library(viridis)

content.label: data as date
content.value:
# import data
data <- read.csv(("path/to/file") ,
                stringsAsFactors=FALSE)
data$date <- as.Date(data$date, format = "%d/%m/%y")

source("path/to/theme.R")

snippets.description: Let’s Git Started -- Beginner’s Guide to Git & Github
snippets.name: git

content.label: Fragment 1
content.value:
# cambia de directorio
~ % cd ~/path/to/repo		

# lista archivos del directorio
  % ls									

# da el estado del repositorio
git status

# sube todo lo que haya cambiado al estrado
git add .

# saca foto y la almacena en la bitácora con un comentario 
git commit -m 'Comentario'  

# lista los alias del repositorio en tu máquina y en github ( master y origin por default)
git remote -v

# jala cambios de origin (alias del repo en tu github) a master (alias del repo en tu máquina)
git pull origin master 

# empuja cambios de master (alias del repo en tu máquina) a origin (alias del repo en tu github)
git push origin master

# visita la foto identificada por un número
git checkout num-del-commit

# regresa a la foto más reciente del repositorio
git checkout master

# listar commits de manera abreviada
git log --pretty=oneline --abbrev-commit

# Undoes all commits after [commit], preserving changes locally 
git reset [commit]

# Discards all history and changes back to the specified commit
git reset --hard [commit]

# forzar un push (cuando se borra un commit local)
## Revisar: https://7sabores.com/blog/como-revertir-un-push-git
git push origin +master
git push --force

snippets.description: The unikn package provides useful color functions — by defining dedicated colors and color palettes, and commands for finding, changing, viewing, and using them — and styled text elements (e.g., for marking, underlining, or plotting colored titles) in R.
snippets.name: colors-palette

content.label: code
content.value:
#-----
library(unikn)

# define colors and color names -- as vectors
paleta.colores <- c("#000000", # color 1
										"#000000", # color 2
                    "#000000") # coolor 3

paleta.degradado <- usecol(c("#000000", "#000000", "#000000"), n = 4)

# see color palettes
seecol(paleta.colores, 			# a color palette
			 col_brd = "white", 	# color and width of borders
       lwd_brd = 5, 				
       title = "") 					# plot title

content.label: example code
content.value:
# example code
color_google <- c("#4285f4", "#34a853", "#fbbc05", "#ea4335")
names_google <- c("blueberry", "sea green", "selective yellow", "cinnabar")

pal_google <- newpal(color_google, names_google)

# inspect color palette
seecol(pal_google, 
       col_brd = "white", lwd_brd = 8,
       main = "Colors of the Google logo")
       
olives  <- grepal("olive", plot = FALSE)
oranges <- grepal("orange", plot = FALSE)

# see color palettes -- more than 1 palette
seecol(pal = list(olives, oranges), 
       pal_names = c("olives", "oranges"), 
       main = "Comparing olives with oranges")

snippets.description: Code for styling plots in RStudio.
snippets.name: style

content.label: tittle/subtitle and axis names
content.value:
# add tittle/subtitle and axis names
labs(title = "Lorem Ipsum",
		 subtitle = "Lorem Ipsum",
		 x = "Lorem Ipsum",
     y = "Lorem Ipsum")

content.label: axis limits
content.value:
# axis limits
ylim(ymin, yend) 
xlim(xmin, xend)

content.label: annotate
content.value:
# create a circle
annotate(geom = "point", x = as.Date("yyyy-mm-dd"), 
					y = y, size = 10, shape = 21, fill = "transparent")
    
# add text to circle
annotate(geom = "text", x = as.Date("yyyy-mm-dd"), 
					y = y, label = "Lorem Ipsum")

snippets.description: Library to convert HTML Tables to Excel file.
snippets.name: html2excel

content.label: commands
content.value:
# install
pip install html2excel

# code
python3 -m html2excel input_file output_file

content.label: as package
content.value:
# using as package
from html2excel import ExcelParser

input_file = '/tmp/text_file.html'
output_file = '/tmp/converted_file.xlsx'

parser = ExcelParser(input_file)
parser.to_excel(output_file)

snippets.description: A command line spreadsheet format converter.
snippets.name: ssconvert

content.label: commands
content.value:
# install
brew install gnumeric

# convert all files from xlsx to csv
ssconvert *.xlsx *.csv

# concatenate all csv files and name the new file all.csv
cat *.csv >> all.csv

# list the file all.csv
ls all.csv

# other info
https://linux.die.net/man/1/ssconvert

content.label: example
content.value:
# convert all file from xlsx to csv
ssconvert 1-01.xlsx 1-01.csv
